title: The Risk of Marginal Rank Revisited
section: Received wisdom: Appearing in a prominent firm ranking is generally beneficial for external perceptions
text:
Received wisdom: Appearing in a prominent firm ranking is generally beneficial for external perceptions

Being ranked provides reputational advantages and disproprotionate resource access (Rindova et al. 2018; Sharkey, Kovacs, and Hsu 2022)
Managers expend significant resources to be ranked (Carlos and Lewis 2018; Dineen and Allen 2016; Meneghetti and Williams 2017)

title: The Risk of Marginal Rank Revisited
text:
What LC23 tells us

The regression discontinuity design (RDD) provides counterfactual comparisons of firms just within and just outside a new ranking (Best Corporate Citizens list)
The DV (abnormal returns) captures immediate investor reactions to the ranking, ruling out managerial explanations

e.g., it’s NOT managers making risky/poor decisions in response to low rank

title: The Risk of Marginal Rank Revisited
text:
What LC23 cannot tell us

Best Corporate Citizen (BCC) ranked firms according to their CSR performance, a contested practice at the time (1999)
Investors may simply
An alternate explanation is that appearing in a CSR ranking was a negative signal of performance to investors
Thus: is the risk of marginal ranking context- and audience-specific, or a more general liability?

title: The Risk of Marginal Rank Revisited
text:
Need for quasi-replication

Increased need for replication in strategic management (Bettis et al. 2016; Bettis, Helfat, and Shaver 2016)
Rankings are growing in their prevalance and importance for non-market strategy (Wendy Nelson Espeland, Sauder, and Espeland 2016; Rindova et al. 2018)
If the risk of being ranked generalizes, we need to revise theoretical accounts of rankings and to redefine prescriptions for managers

title: The Risk of Marginal Rank Revisited
text:
Summary of Findings

Marginal inclusion in F500 ranking associated with 1.3% decrease in firm value
For Fortune Most Admired Company subsample, marginal F500 inclusion associated with 0.25 drop in reputation score (~0.5 standard deviation)
Other analyses: effects are driven by the ‘newly elevated’ (service firms), not the ‘newly diminished’ (i.e., original F500 now ranked lower)

Towards broader theoretical account
Risk of ranking is independent of:

The basis of the ranking
The newness of the ranking

Generalizes to multiple audiences with different values:

Investors assessing value
Executive peers assessing reputation

title: The Risk of Marginal Rank Revisited
text:
Towards broader theoretical account

Audiences evaluate firms within consideration sets (Moliterno et al. 2014)
Rankings sort and categorize: defining consideration sets (Bowers and Prato 2018)
Thus, lower-ranked firms are compared unfavorably to higher-ranked firms
Also, ranking amplifies the importance of the ranking variable in assessing firm quality, thus obscuring lower-ranked firms points of differentiation (W. N. Espeland and Stevens 1998)

title: The Risk of Marginal Rank Revisited
text:
Boundary conditions

Rankings with churn (e.g., not awards)
Explicit ordering (e.g., not simply ‘Top 100’)
Larger rankings

title: The Risk of Marginal Rank Revisited
text:
Implications for practice

Pursue rankings where performance unequivocal
If marginally ranked, emphasize categorical membership rather than specific rank

title: Software
text:
tidyhte
tidyhte provides tidy semantics for estimation of heterogeneous treatment effects through the use of Kennedy’s (n.d.) doubly-robust learner.
The goal of tidyhte is to use a sort of “recipe” design. This should (hopefully) make it extremely easy to scale an analysis of HTE from the common single-outcome / single-moderator case to many outcomes and many moderators. The configuration of tidyhte should make it extremely easy to perform the same analysis across many outcomes and for a wide-array of moderators. It’s written to be fairly easy to extend to different models and to add additional diagnostics and ways to output information from a set of HTE estimates.

        
        Website
     
        
        Github
    
regweight
The goal of regweight is to make it easy to diagnose a model using Aronow and Samii (2015) regression weights.
In short, these weights show which observations are most influential for determining the observed value of a coefficient in a linear regression. If the linear regression is aiming to estimate causal effects, this implies that the OLS estimand may differ from the average treatment effect. These linear regression weights provide, in some sense, the most precise estimate available given a conditioning set (and a linear model). These weights are in expectation the conditional variance of the variable of interest (given the other covariates in the model).

        
        Website
     
        
        Github
     
        
        Package
    
rdd
Outdated! Users should switch to actively maintained and updated RD tools.
Provides the tools to undertake estimation in Regression Discontinuity Designs. Both sharp and fuzzy designs are supported. Estimation is accomplished using local linear regression. A provided function will utilize Imbens-Kalyanaraman optimal bandwidth calculation. A function is also included to test the assumption of no-sorting effects.

e.g., it’s NOT managers making risky/poor decisions in response to low rank

title: Exploratory Interviews
text:
Summary of Findings

Marginal inclusion in F500 ranking associated with 1.3% decrease in firm value
For Fortune Most Admired Company subsample, marginal F500 inclusion associated with 0.25 drop in reputation score (~0.5 standard deviation)
Other analyses: effects are driven by the ‘newly elevated’ (service firms), not the ‘newly diminished’ (i.e., original F500 now ranked lower)

title: Exploratory Interviews
text:
Towards broader theoretical account
Risk of ranking is independent of:

The basis of the ranking
The newness of the ranking

Generalizes to multiple audiences with different values:

Investors assessing value
Executive peers assessing reputation

title: Exploratory Interviews
text:
Towards broader theoretical account

Audiences evaluate firms within consideration sets (Moliterno et al. 2014)
Rankings sort and categorize: defining consideration sets (Bowers and Prato 2018)
Thus, lower-ranked firms are compared unfavorably to higher-ranked firms
Also, ranking amplifies the importance of the ranking variable in assessing firm quality, thus obscuring lower-ranked firms points of differentiation (W. N. Espeland and Stevens 1998)

title: Exploratory Interviews
text:
Boundary conditions

Rankings with churn (e.g., not awards)
Explicit ordering (e.g., not simply ‘Top 100’)
Larger rankings

title: Exploratory Interviews
text:
Implications for practice

Pursue rankings where performance unequivocal
If marginally ranked, emphasize categorical membership rather than specific rank
